ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a better understanding of French grammar and practiced listening and speaking French.
I learned speaking a lot more in this class and listening.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: the Professor is a wonderful instructor and was very accommodating to the needs of the students. I really appreciated how she took time to explain some of the nuances and differences between actual spoken French in France, and the French we learned in class. Weaknesses: we received very few grades throughout the semester, so it was difficult to gage our standing and receive feedback. It would have been nice to have had more feedback on our spoken exams and compositions in order to know where we needed to improve. We could not see our cumulative grades in canvas for the whole semester. In terms of the general L2 curriculum, it seems like the French Department values quantity over quality because we learned a host of new tenses this semester but I did not feel like we spent enough time learning about the nuances of each and how to properly employ them, which made the course more challenging than it needed to be. Overall, I did enjoy this course, and would take another class from this Professor as well.
This course was very strong in participation and consistent work. Professor was very engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Practicing a new language over Zoom was really difficult. I think more time dedicated to getting to know our other classmates would have facilitated better interactions over zoom.
Lectures will still very engaging despite Covid.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would, but I would urge the French department to reevaluate the amount of information covered in the L2 curriculum in order to allow us more time to become comfortable with everything presented. This would be especially beneficial for students who are looking to become fluent.
I would it is a great course when taught by the right professor.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
